responses.message: Apple scab is a common fungal disease caused by Venturia inaequalis. It appears as olive-green to black spots on leaves and fruit, which can lead to cracking. Control by using fungicide sprays, removing fallen leaves in the autumn, and selecting scab-resistant varieties.

The codling moth is a major pest for apples. Larvae tunnel into the fruit, making them unmarketable. Management includes applying insecticide at key times, using pheromone traps to disrupt mating, and removing infested fruit from the tree.

patterns: clusters of small insects on new growth

responses.message: Aphids are small sap-sucking insects that can cause leaves to curl and stunt new growth. They excrete sticky honeydew which attracts sooty mold. Control by spraying with insecticidal soap or neem oil, and encouraging natural predators like ladybugs.

patterns: blossoms and shoots suddenly turn brown or black
shepherd's crook shape on new shoots

responses.message: Fire blight is a serious bacterial disease of apples. Infected areas appear scorched, and new shoots often form a characteristic 'shepherd's crook.' Control by pruning infected branches at least 12 inches below the visible damage, and applying antibiotic sprays during flowering.

patterns: dark brown to black spots on leaves

responses.message: Black Sigatoka is a widespread fungal disease caused by Pseudocercospora fijiensis. It causes yellow streaks that develop into large, black spots on the leaves, leading to premature leaf death and reduced fruit yield. Control includes applying specific fungicides, pruning and removing affected leaves, and using resistant varieties.

patterns: yellowing and wilting of older leaves

responses.message: Panama disease (Fusarium wilt) is a destructive soil-borne fungal disease caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. cubense. Symptoms start with wilting and yellowing of the lower leaves and can lead to the entire plant dying. There is no effective chemical control; management relies on sanitation, quarantines, and planting resistant varieties.

patterns: tunnels in the corm and pseudostem

responses.message: The banana weevil is a serious insect pest. Larvae tunnel through the corm and pseudostem, weakening the plant and making it susceptible to toppling. Control includes using weevil-free planting material, trapping, and applying insecticides to the base of the plant.

patterns: small purple or red spots on leaves

responses.message: Cherry leaf spot is a fungal disease caused by Blumeriella jaapii. It presents as small, circular purple to red spots on leaves, which then turn yellow and drop prematurely. Control by applying fungicides at bud break and every 7-10 days after rain, and by sanitizing the area to remove fallen leaves.

patterns: soft or sunken spots on fruit

responses.message: The cherry fruit fly larvae (maggots) feed on the fruit pulp, making the cherries unfit for consumption. Control includes timely application of insecticide sprays as fruit begins to color and using sticky traps to monitor adult flies.

Brown rot is a fungal disease that affects fruit as it ripens. It causes soft, brown spots that quickly spread, with gray spore masses appearing on the surface. Control with fungicide sprays during the flowering and ripening stages, and by removing and destroying infected fruit.

Citrus greening (Huanglongbing) is a devastating bacterial disease spread by the Asian citrus psyllid. It causes mottled leaves, stunted growth, and bitter, misshapen fruit. There is no cure; the focus is on preventing the spread by controlling the psyllid population and removing infected trees.

patterns: lesions with yellow halo on fruit

responses.message: Citrus canker is a highly contagious bacterial disease that causes raised, brown lesions on the leaves, stems, and fruit. It can reduce fruit quality and cause premature fruit drop. Control measures include copper-based sprays and pruning out affected branches.

The citrus leafminer is a small moth whose larvae tunnel through young leaves, creating characteristic winding 'mines.' This can weaken the tree and make it more susceptible to other diseases. Control with horticultural oils or specific insecticides during the flush of new growth.

Botrytis fruit rot (gray mold) is a common fungal disease that affects strawberry fruit, causing soft, brown spots that are often covered with a fuzzy gray mold. Control by using fungicide sprays, improving air circulation around plants, and harvesting fruit before it becomes overripe.

Powdery mildew is a fungal disease that appears as a white, powdery coating on strawberry leaves, which may cause them to curl upwards. Control with sulfur dust, baking soda solutions, or specific fungicides, and ensure adequate spacing for air flow.

The strawberry weevil, also known as the 'clipper,' is an insect that cuts the flower buds from the plant, preventing fruit from forming. Control by clearing plant debris where they may overwinter, and using insecticides if the infestation is severe.

patterns: black spots on leaves and fruit

responses.message: Mango anthracnose is a fungal disease that can cause black spots on leaves, flowers, and fruit, and lead to significant yield loss. Control by using copper-based fungicides, pruning to increase air circulation, and removing infected plant parts.

Mango hoppers are small insects that suck sap from flowers and new leaves, causing them to wilt and dry. They excrete sticky honeydew which promotes sooty mold. Control by spraying with neem oil or systemic insecticides during the flowering stage.

Gummy stem blight is a serious fungal disease that causes lesions on stems with a characteristic 'gummy' ooze. Control with crop rotation, proper sanitation, and preventive fungicide applications, especially in humid conditions.

Fusarium wilt is a soil-borne fungal disease that causes a progressive wilting of the watermelon vine. There is no chemical cure; management involves using resistant varieties, long-term crop rotation, and soil fumigation.

Pineapple mealybug wilt is caused by a virus transmitted by mealybugs. Symptoms include wilting and reddening of leaves, and root decay. Control is focused on managing mealybug populations with insecticides and planting virus-free material.

patterns: yellowing and wilting of inner leaves
foul smell from the plant base

responses.message: Heart rot is a fungal disease that rots the central part of the pineapple plant. Control by ensuring good soil drainage, avoiding overhead irrigation, and applying fungicides to the plant's 'heart' as a preventive measure.

Mummy berry is a fungal disease that causes shoots to blight and fruit to shrivel into hard, inedible 'mummies.' Control by using fungicides during the budding and flowering stages, and by removing and destroying infected plant material.

patterns: orange or pink spore masses on lesions

responses.message: Anthracnose fruit rot causes sunken lesions on ripening blueberries. Control by applying fungicides at key growth stages, ensuring good air circulation, and avoiding harvesting wet fruit.
The pomegranate fruit borer is a caterpillar that tunnels into the fruit, making it vulnerable to rot. Control involves timely application of insecticides and removing and destroying infested fruit.

patterns: small, dark brown spots on leaves

responses.message: Leaf spot is a fungal disease that causes small, dark spots on pomegranate leaves, which can lead to premature leaf drop. Control is achieved by pruning to improve air circulation and applying fungicides.
